rev.comment: Not 6th of October City one, he was in Nasr City
rev.diff:
Line 24: Line 24:
and the [[Workers Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/5/2/headlines/egypt_celebrates_international_workers_day_for_first_time_since_1952 | title=Egypt Celebrates International Workersâ Day for First Time Since 1952 | publisher=Democracy Now | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=14 May 2011}}</ref> He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]] where he was detained and [[torture]]d by the [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI) in 2000, allegedly with the institution's complicity.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
and the [[Workers Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.democracynow.org/2011/5/2/headlines/egypt_celebrates_international_workers_day_for_first_time_since_1952 | title=Egypt Celebrates International Workersâ Day for First Time Since 1952 | publisher=Democracy Now | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=14 May 2011}}</ref> He is a graduate of the [[American University in Cairo]] where he was detained and [[torture]]d by the [[State Security Investigations Service]] (SSI) in 2000, allegedly with the institution's complicity.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/9286/Egypt/Politics-/Students-of-Egypts-American-University-question-it.aspx | title=Students of Egypt's American University question its ties to Mubarak's regime | publisher=Ahram Online | date=7 April 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
â
After the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in the [[6th of October City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
+
After the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] of 2011, el-Hamalawy was among many protesters who stormed and seized offices of the SSI in the [[Nasr City]] and was able to visit the cell where he had been imprisoned, later writing on his [[Twitter]] feed that he could not stop crying.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/world/middleeast/10cairo.html?hp | title=Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying | publisher=The New York Times | date=9 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> "Entered the small compound where I was locked. Man, I can't believe it still... Many are literally crying. We can't find the interrogation rooms. This is a citadel."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title=A first step towards prosecutions? | publisher=Al Jazeera | date=6 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref>
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos, and anyone with information can post a comment, much like users on [[Wikipedia]] do. "The tables are turned," said el-Hamalawy, "We will be doing investigations on you; we will be profiling you".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
Since storming the SSI offices, el-Hamalawy has become the main force behind a "naming and shaming" website targeting former SSI personnel who were involved in the alleged torture of dissidents. Their names are linked to allegations and photos, and anyone with information can post a comment, much like users on [[Wikipedia]] do. "The tables are turned," said el-Hamalawy, "We will be doing investigations on you; we will be profiling you".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/egypts-activists-turn-tables-on-tormentors/2011/04/30/AFEdLV1G_print.html | title=Egyptâs activists turn tables on tormentors | publisher=The Washington Post | date=13 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref>
